an4.243:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
an4.243:4.2: Then venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha,
an4.243:4.3: bowed, and sat down to one side.
an4.243:4.5: “Well, Ānanda, has that disciplinary issue been settled yet?”
an4.243:4.7: Venerable Anuruddha’s pupil Bāhiya remains entirely committed to creating a schism in the Saṅgha.
an4.243:4.8: But Anuruddha doesn’t think to say a single word about it.”
an4.243:5.1: “But Ānanda, since when has Anuruddha been involved in disciplinary issues in the midst of the Saṅgha?
an4.243:5.2: Shouldn’t you, together with Sāriputta and Moggallāna, settle all disciplinary issues that come up?
an4.243:6.1: A bad monk sees four reasons to relish schism in the Saṅgha.
an4.243:6.3: Take an unethical monk, of bad qualities, filthy, with suspicious behavior, secretive, no true ascetic or spiritual practitioner—though claiming to be one—rotten inside, corrupt, and depraved.
an4.243:6.5: ‘Suppose the monks know that I’m a bad monk …
an4.243:6.6: If they’re in harmony, they’ll expel me,
an4.243:6.7: but if they’re divided they won’t.’
an4.243:6.8: A bad monk sees this as the first reason to relish schism in the Saṅgha.
an4.243:7.1: Furthermore, a bad monk has wrong view, he’s attached to an extremist view.
an4.243:7.3: ‘Suppose the monks know that I have wrong view …
an4.243:7.4: If they’re in harmony they’ll expel me,
an4.243:7.5: but if they’re divided they won’t.’
an4.243:7.6: A bad monk sees this as the second reason to relish schism in the Saṅgha.
an4.243:8.1: Furthermore, a bad monk has wrong livelihood and earns a living by wrong livelihood.
an4.243:8.3: ‘Suppose the monks know that I have wrong livelihood …
an4.243:8.4: If they’re in harmony they’ll expel me,
an4.243:8.5: but if they’re divided they won’t.’
an4.243:8.6: A bad monk sees this as the third reason to relish schism in the Saṅgha.
an4.243:9.1: Furthermore, a bad monk desires material possessions, honor, and admiration.
an4.243:9.3: ‘Suppose the monks know that I desire material possessions, honor, and admiration.
an4.243:9.4: If they’re in harmony they won’t honor, respect, revere, or worship me,
an4.243:9.5: but if they’re divided they will.’
an4.243:9.6: A bad monk sees this as the fourth reason to relish schism in the Saṅgha.
an4.243:9.7: A bad monk sees these four reasons to relish schism in the Saṅgha.”
